references: To explain the reasons behind the choice of 12 and 16 kB as the FL model sizes for Figs.Â 2a and 2c, TableÂ II shows the conditions under which CB for NR PUSCH with retransmissions on dedicated resources provides lower model upload times w.r.t DS as a function of the model size, PFLsubscriptğ‘ƒFLP_{\rm FL}, and maximum bandwidth allowed for CB transmissions BCBsubscriptğµCBB_{\rm CB} (out of the overall system bandwidth BğµB) when considering NFL=subscriptğ‘FLabsentN_{\rm FL}= 30. As can be seen, independently of the considered BCBsubscriptğµCBB_{\rm CB} value, a model size of 12 kB is the maximum value for which the considered CB design provides benefits over DS, thereby motivating the model size choice of Fig.Â 2a. Of course, the same holds for the model download times, i.e., 16 kB is the maximum model size for which there are gains, as well as when considering the design employing retransmissions on CB resources.

references: Next, in TableÂ III we show the average collision probability, pCÂ¯Â¯superscriptğ‘C\overline{p^{\rm C}}, and average iteration time, Ï„IÂ¯Â¯superscriptğœI\overline{\tau^{\rm I}}, when considering the model size of 2 MB, and the considered CB for NR PUSCH with retransmissions on dedicated resources. It can be seen that the average iteration times can be tens of seconds even for low loads, thus indicating that a FL training can be quite large if it involved higher loads (i.e., a non-negligible training phase has to be performed before having FL-based cameras ready to perform image recognition).
